So traditional biscotti
is a very simple cookie
that you can make by hand.
We add 250 grams or just shy
of two cups of all purpose flour,
one teaspoon baking powder,
1/2 teaspoon of kosher salt,
and 1/4 teaspoon of baking soda.
Tiny whisk together to evenly distribute

the salt and leaveners
throughout the flour.

Then, in a separate,
slightly smaller bowl,
we're gonna combine our wet stuff,
starting with three large eggs
that we're gonna crack in there,
which we're gonna whisk together
with 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract
and one teaspoon almond extract,
along with our sugar,
175 grams or just shy of a cup.

Go ahead and whisk together
until it's relatively smooth.

Doesn't need to be fluffy
or fully dissolved.
Then it's time to bring everybody together
in addition to 120 grams
or about 2/3 of a cup of whole almonds,
which you can see I'm being pedantic

about making sure that
each one is cut in half.

Come on, any of you have
better things to do?
Okay, here we go.
Dump those on into the flour,
along with the egg and sugar mixture.

And then we just gotta
mix everybody together

using a rubber spatula until
no dry pockets of flour remain.

And since biscotti are pretty
dry and don't have much fat,

we don't have to worry
as much about overmixing
as we normally would with other cookies.

We want these to be dry and
snappy when they come out,

so if you overdevelop
the gluten, no big deal.

Next up, we're prepping
a rimmed baking sheet
with nonstick spray.
I like to spray an X in the center,
then more around each edge,

which is gonna hold our sheet
of parchment paper in place.
Press that down until it's nice and flat,
and then dump the cookie dough on top.
And then, using lightly-wetted fingers
so the dough doesn't stick,
we're gonna shape this thing
into a sort of uniform log thing,

the width of which is going to
determine your final cookies.
This thing is gonna more than double
in size in the oven, so plan accordingly.

Speaking of which, that's
where it's headed next:

a 350 degree Fahrenheit
oven for 25 to 30 minutes
until the dough emerges triumphant,

puffy, not too deeply
browned, and well set.

And we're letting this
guy cool for 10 minutes,

during which time we're gonna
lower our oven temperature
to 300 degrees Fahrenheit.
Pop this guy off the sheet tray
by virtue of the parchment paper,
and then it's time to begin slicing.

As you can see, the dough is
pretty set all the way through.
The knife isn't dragging.
Nothing's getting pinched on wet dough.

So we'll end up with biscotti
that has nice, clean facades.

Go ahead and slice her
up as evenly as you can,

which in my case is not
terribly evenly at all.

Keep the end pieces as
snacks for the chef.

And then it's time to lay these
guys back out on parchment

on their sides to bake once
again at a lower temperature.
The word biscotti, after all,
is derived from the Latin biscoctus.
Pretty interesting, huh? No?
Yeah, you're right.
These guys are now headed

into the 300 degree Fahrenheit
oven for 10 to 15 minutes

or until their skyward
facade feels relatively dry.
Then, we're giving 'em a flip,

and back into the oven they go
for another 10 to 15 minutes
until once again dry on the other side.

Let 'em cool completely on the
tray, and there you have it:
super easy, super classic almond biscotti,

which by any cookie metric
is pretty dry and crisp,
which in its current form is pretty good.
But really, this thing is designed to be

in accompaniment to hot coffee
or even sweet dessert wine,

something it can soak up
to make it more palatable,
kinda like breakfast cereal and milk.

And this might've been okay
for Italians in 300 AD,
but I am an American in the 21st century,
so I need chocolate and I need fixins.
Chocolate is easy enough.
You can temper it,

if you have that kind
of time on your hands.

But it's also fine to just
melt it in a double boiler.
Just make sure to take it off the heat
as soon as it's melted.

Overheating the chocolate
can make the fat bloom

once it's cooled, which
will taste just fine,

but it'll be covered
in weird white streaks.

Once you've dipped the
bottom of the biscotti

into the chocolate and
let the excess drip off,
it's time to place it chocolate side down

on yet another
parchment-lined baking sheet

so it can solidify,
improving the biscotti,
your coffee, and your day.

And if you wanna throw some
twists on the original recipe,
here's how you do it.
First, like all things in life,

this process is made inexorably
easier by a stand mixer,

so if you got one of those,
go ahead and bust it out.
Then for this first variation,
I've got 60 grams of dried cranberries

and 80 grams of unsalted
shelled pistachios,

which, just like the almonds,
are gonna end up nicer

if you give 'em a little
toast in a 400 degree oven.
And, of course, let 'em cool completely
before adding them to the batter.
From there, it's the same procedure:
mix it all up, form it into a log,

bake it, slice it up, lay
it out, bake it again,

flip 'em over, bake 'em again,
let 'em cool completely,

and this time, we're gonna
dip them in white chocolate,

which, as you can see, I'm
pouring into a tall narrow glass,

so as that we might envelop
half of our biscotti
in the chocolate.

Now, I'm not even that big
of a fan of white chocolate,
but even I can't resist when it's combined

and dipped into coffee,
and smothered in sprinkles,

and maybe I just don't
like white chocolate.

So let's make a chocolate
chocolate orange biscotti.
Same recipe as before,

but we're substituting
50 grams of the flour
with Dutch process cocoa powder.

Then, instead of any
stupid nuts or berries,
we're gonna add more chocolate:

120 grams of your
favorite baking chocolate,
roughly chopped into chunks.
Add that along with the wet stuff,

and then just to try to keep
things a little bit healthy,

we'll add some fruit: the
zest of one large orange,

which of course is not
gonna make things healthy,
but bring a nice, subtle orange flavor.
Same deal from there:

mix everything up, pat it
out, bake, slice, bake.

And there you have it: double
chocolate orange biscotti,

which are almost perfect as
they are, but we're not done.

Another common topping for
biscotti is a thin fondant icing,

which we're gonna make by
squeezing the juice of one orange
and adding it a little bit at a time
to two cups of powdered sugar,

until it has a nice, thick
but drizzleable consistency.

You can even add a drop or
two of orange food coloring

if you really wanna hammer
home that this is orange.
Now, your best move is probably

to just Jackson Pollock
this all over your cookies,
but after making so many,
I fancied myself a bit of a pastry artist,
which turned out not to be true.
So while these don't look awesome

for Halloween biscotti,
they're really, really delicious.

so Italians legally cannot get mad at me.
